  • Reference

Adds a variable (or a set of variables) to a dataset by a sliding window approach.

Source: R/slidingWindow.R
slidingWindow.Rd

Adds a variable (or a set of variables) to a dataset by a sliding window approach.

slidingWindow(data, utc_col = character(1), fun, steps, time_in_sec,
  check_fun = TRUE, eval_at_rows = numeric(0), unit = "s")

Arguments

data

dataframe.
utc_col

character. Column name of the UTC timestamp.
fun

function. A function that has `data`` as input and a dataframe with 1 row as output.
steps

integer. Number of steps which the sliding window should go back. Use this for data with fixed sample rate.
time_in_sec

integer. Number of seconds which the sliding window should go back. Use this for data with variable sample rate.
check_fun

logical. If TRUE, fun(data) will be evaluated and checked, if the outcome is of correct form. Set to FALSE, if evaluation on the whole dataset takes too long.
eval_at_rows

integer. Integer vector at which rows the function should be executed. Defaults to `1:nrow(data)`.
unit

unit of the timestamps. Can be 's' or 'ms'. Defaults to 's' (seconds).

Value

dataframe with added column(s).

See also

Other helper functions: addColumnByGroup, addColumn, addDateTime, addDate, addStudyDayByGroup, addStudyDay, addTime, addWeekday, calcStudyDay, divideDataIntoIntervals

Examples

fun = function(x) data.frame(mean.accuracy.last30 = mean(x$accuracy, na.rm = TRUE),
  max.accuracy.last30 = max(x$accuracy, na.rm = TRUE))
data = studentlife.small[1:30, ] #needs date_time variable
slidingWindow(data, fun = fun, time_in_sec = 60 * 60,
  utc_col = "timestamp") #mean accuracy of last hour
